text: there was quite some celebration in
central Athens tonight
Greece's no voters felt proud of
themselves like their controversial
Prime Minister they stood up today to
their country's powerful creditors the
IMF and the European Union after five
years of hopeless austerity misery their
message was clear no more there's no
money but little by little we'll be ok
we're hungry before and now we'll stay
hungry so at least we stood up today to
angular America the new voters here in
Syntagma Square are delighted to have
got their voice of protest heard but
behind the music and the celebration is
a sense of confusion and a fear whatever
Greeks voted today yes or no the vast
majority say they want to stay inside
the eurozone but will that be possible
wheat banks are shut and fast running
out of money and no one knows what's
going to happen tomorrow television
coverage of the referendum here was as
self-conscious as it was dramatic Greeks
know the rest of Europe is watching with
bated breath the impact of today's vote
will be felt not only in Greece but
throughout the eurozone buoyed by the
backing of their people which they say
strengthens their bargaining position
the Greek government now is upbeat about
finding a new bailout deal with this now
we will try to cooperate with our
partners and we will invite them one by
one we see if we can find some common
ground and we will try to be positive as
of tomorrow Greece will go back to the
table negotiation tables and our primary
drivers like at the my priority is to
reinstate the financial stability of the
country
but is that realistic or are Greeks
celebrating the no vote tonight dancing
on the edge of a precipice Greece now
has to wait for the reaction of its
eurozone partners it could just have
taken a big step closer to falling out
of the single currency Kathy Adler BBC
news Athens
